Investments in warehouse automation, early inventory procurement, and logistics optimization to mitigate rising costs and supply chain issues.

Completed on August 3, 2020 for $245.0 million using cash on hand and an existing credit facility. Included a 360,000 sq ft state-of-the-art production/distribution facility; reported revenue of approximately $171.2 million for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2020.
Completed on October 27, 2021 for $20.0 million using the existing credit facility. Vital Choice’s reported revenue was approximately $27.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Completed on December 31, 2021 using existing cash ($0.8 million), conversion of accounts receivable ($0.3 million), and a previous investment ($0.3 million). Reported revenue was approximately $3.8 million for the twelve-month period ended September 30, 2021.

Initiated on August 20, 2020 as a First Amendment to the 2019 Credit Agreement. Key changes include: increasing the revolving credit facility from $200.0 million to $250.0 million, establishing a $100.0 million term A-1 loan (maturing May 31, 2024) with tiered interest rates, and adjusting working capital and seasonal sublimits.
PersonalizationMall (acquired on August 3, 2020), Vital Choice (acquired on October 27, 2021), Shari’s Berries (acquired in August 2019), Alice's Table (acquired on December 31, 2021)

Post-pandemic fiscal 2022 revenues exceeded pre-pandemic fiscal 2019 revenues by 76.8%. Excluding revenues from these acquisitions, pro-forma revenue growth exceeded pre-pandemic fiscal 2019 revenues by 48.8%.

data.key: Net Revenues Growth FY Ended June 27, 2021
data.value: Net revenues increased 42.5% compared to the prior year. Excluding PersonalizationMall.com, total net revenues grew 26.6% compared to the prior year.

Challenges included slowing consumer demand, limited production and distribution labor, global supply-chain disruptions, shortages of key components, geopolitical turmoil, commodity shortages, rapid price inflation, and increased digital marketing costs.

The Company accounts for business combinations in accordance with ASC Topic 805.
The acquiring entity must recognize the fair value of all the assets acquired and liabilities assumed.
Recognition of acquisition-related costs in the consolidated results of operations.
Recognition of restructuring costs in the consolidated results for which the acquirer becomes obligated after the acquisition date.
Contingent purchase consideration to be recognized at their fair values on the acquisition date.
Fair values assigned to identifiable intangible assets acquired are determined primarily by using an income approach.
The excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the identified assets and liabilities is recorded as goodwill.
Operating results of the acquired entity are reflected in the Company’s consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition.

elements.title: Preliminary Purchase Price Allocation and Acquisition Details

data.value: $20.3 million

After working capital and related adjustments, the total consideration was preliminarily allocated to identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Final adjustments may affect carrying values, intangible asset useful lives, and goodwill.

Table titled 'Preliminary Purchase Price Allocation Comparison' with the following breakdown: Inventory: initial allocation 8653; Other current assets: 929 with a -474 adjustment resulting in 455; Property, plant and equipment: 205 with a -205 adjustment resulting in 0; Intangible assets: 9800; Goodwill: 4383 with a +34 adjustment resulting in 4417; Total assets acquired: 23970 with a -645 adjustment to 23325; Current liabilities: 3621 with a -256 adjustment to 3365; Net assets acquired: 20349 with a -389 adjustment to 19960.

The fair value of the acquired inventory was determined using the income approach (net retail value less operating expenses and profit allowance). Raw materials were valued at book value. For intangible assets, customer lists ($4.5M, amortized over 5 years) were valued using the excess earnings method; tradenames ($5.3M, indefinite life) were valued using the relief from royalty method; and goodwill ($4.4M, indefinite) is expected to be tax-deductible.
The operating results of the Vital Choice business are reflected in the consolidated financial statements under the Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets segment.
Certain immaterial adjustments have been booked during the current quarter, and the final allocation may result in additional adjustments.

The stock options activity during the year ending July 3, 2022 is summarized as follows: Beginning balance of 336,700 options at an average exercise price of $3.44, 321,700 options were exercised at $2.63, and 15,000 options were forfeited or expired at $20.72. By the end of the period, there were no outstanding or exercisable options.

The Company offers a wide range of products including fresh-cut flowers, floral and fruit arrangements and plants, gifts, personalized products, dipped berries, popcorn, gourmet foods and gift baskets, cookies, chocolates, candy, wine, and gift-quality fruit.
The Company’s product development team works closely with its production team to select and design its floral, gourmet foods and gift baskets, as well as other gift-related products.
The Company intends to continue to develop differentiated products and signature collections that customers expect.
Flags hip brand offers fresh-cut flowers and arrangements for all occasions, available for same-day delivery.

elements.title: Strategic Investments and Initiatives Amid Macroeconomic Shifts

data.value: As the pandemic waned, the company experienced dramatic shifts including rising inflation, disrupted global supply chains, and a tight labor market.
The company used its balance sheet to invest in its operating platform with initiatives such as automating warehouse and distribution facilities.
Early inventory buildup and logistics optimization programs were implemented to mitigate global supply chain issues and rising shipping costs.
Proactive measures including automation and strategic pricing programs are aimed at managing labor costs and improving gross margins and bottom-line results.
Enhanced bundled product offerings and multiple engagement initiatives (emails, podcasts, blogs, virtual workshops) contributed to significant customer growth and increased average order value.
July 3, 2022
The table presents a comprehensive overview of the company's material properties, including offices, plants, warehouses, and agricultural land across various U.S. locations.

Locations, facility types, usage, sizes, and ownership status (owned/leased) are provided for properties in Medford, OR; Bolingbrook, IL; Hebron, OH; Atlanta, GA; Melrose Park, IL; Obetz, OH; Jacksonville, FL; Lake Forest, IL; Burr Ridge, IL; Jericho, NY; Westerville, OH; Reno, NV; Memphis, TN; Jackson County, OR; and Josephine County, OR.

The summary emphasizes a mix of owned and leased properties with significant agricultural holdings in Oregon, and notes corporate headquarters at Jericho, NY. Subsequent items mention legal proceedings (see Note 17 in Part IV, Item 15) and mine safety disclosures (not applicable).
Purchase commitments

The table shows purchase commitments (in thousands) over a five-year period from 2023 to 2027 and beyond. The highest commitment is in fiscal year 2023 at $169,291,000, with decreasing amounts in subsequent years. The commitments drop significantly after 2023, reaching $148,000 in 2027 with no commitments thereafter. The total purchase commitments across all periods amount to $189,871,000.
July 3, 2022

elements.title: Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: This MD&A section provides insights into the Company's financial condition, cash flow, liquidity, and results of operations.
The Company is a leading provider of gifts with multiple segments including Consumer Floral & Gifts, Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets, and BloomNet.
4.0% increase with total revenues exceeding $2.2 billion
42.5% growth in fiscal 2021 and 76.8% growth compared with fiscal 2019 (48.8% excluding acquisitions)
Rising costs due to inflation, increased labor, shipping, commodities, and digital advertising rates negatively impacted gross margins and operating expenses
A decrease of 500 basis points in gross margin due to cost pressures
Declined from $213.1 million in fiscal 2021 to $99.0 million in fiscal 2022
The discussion includes forward-looking statements and highlights risks associated with macroeconomic conditions and changes in consumer behavior
Execution of performance bonus eliminations for executives contributed to labor cost reductions

elements.title: Table of Contents: Financial Performance Metrics

data.value: Defined as supplemental performance measures used by the Company for evaluating performance, determining incentive compensation for executive officers and employees, setting interest rates under the credit agreement, and evaluating acquisition targets. They do not reflect cash needs for working capital, debt servicing, or future capital expenditures.

Represents earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) before corporate overhead expenses, adjusted for comparability. It is used with GAAP results to provide insight into business segment performance.

data.key: Adjusted Net Income and Adjusted Net Income per Common Share
data.value: Net income and net income per common share adjusted for items affecting period-to-period comparability. These measures are used alongside GAAP figures to enhance comparability.

Calculated as net cash provided by operating activities less capital expenditures. This liquidity measure informs management and investors about cash generation available for reinvestment, strategic acquisitions, balance sheet strengthening, stock repurchase, or debt retirement, while not reflecting the total change in cash balance.

data.key: Net revenues - Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets

data.value: This table presents a detailed financial comparison between July 2022 and June 2021. Key highlights include an increase in total net revenues by 4.0% to $2.21B in 2022, a decline in gross profit margins across segments, and a significant drop in adjusted EBITDA by 53.5%.
July 3, 2022

data.key: Harry & David store closure cost adjustment

data.value: The table reconciles net income to adjusted net income (non-GAAP) comparing periods ending July 3, 2022 and June 27, 2021. Net income decreased significantly from 118,652 to 29,610 while adjusted net income decreased from 122,567 to 32,885. Basic EPS and adjusted EPS also declined.
The table shows that the basic share count slightly increased while the diluted figure decreased, indicating a minor change in the company's share structure or earnings calculation.

This table presents a comparative EBITDA reconciliation for two periods, showing a significant decrease in net income and adjusted EBITDA. Key adjustments include depreciation and amortization, stock-based compensation, and various one-time charges such as litigation settlement and transaction costs.

The net revenues table shows that E-Commerce revenues have grown consistently from 2020 through 2022, while the Other segment experienced volatility with a decline in 2021 followed by a recovery in 2022. Overall, net revenues increased by 4.0% year-over-year, with adjustments for non-comparative impacts.
Years Ended

Consumer Floral & Gifts segment net revenue growth fiscal 2022

data.value: Vital Choice (Oct 27, 2021), PersonalizationMall (Aug 3, 2020), Alice’s Table (Dec 31, 2021)

Gross profit is defined as net revenues less cost of revenues, which includes florist fulfillment costs, cost of merchandise (floral & non-floral), shipping charges, labor, facility costs, and payments to referring florists.
In April 2020, a strategic decision was made to temporarily waive fees and establish health and safety protocols to support member florists during the pandemic.

The Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets segment includes operations of Harry & David, Wolferman’s Bakery, Stock Yards, Cheryl’s Cookies, The Popcorn Factory, 1-800-Baskets/DesignPac, Shari’s Berries (acquired on August 14, 2019), and Vital Choice (acquired on October 27, 2021). Revenue sources include e-commerce, retail, and wholesale channels.
Decreased 8.3% due to a lower gross profit percentage
37.2% after adjusting for acquisitions

Lower margins across segments; supply chain disruptions; increased commodity costs; higher year-over-year labor rates; shipping delays and increased costs including fuel surcharges; write-off of expired perishable inventories
Pricing initiatives, pre-building inventory to offset supply chain delays, logistics optimization for outbound shipping, and deployment of automation to address labor shortages

Consumer Floral & Gifts showed a 1.0% unfavorable change (adjusted pro-forma gross profit percentage of 39.2% for FY2022 vs FY2021), BloomNet segment experienced a 5.3% unfavorable change, and Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets saw a 16.3% unfavorable change due to a drop in gross profit percentage

Gross profit increased significantly in various segments due to revenue growth and improved gross profit margins driven by acquisitions and pricing initiatives, with pro-forma margins noted (e.g., 41.1% and 37.9% for adjusted figures)
Marketing and sales
Percentage of sales

The table shows marketing and sales figures across different time periods from 2020 to 2022. Marketing and sales expenses increased from $363,227k in June 2020 to $571,661k in July 2022, representing significant growth. As a percentage of sales, these expenses increased from 24.4% to 25.9%, indicating a slightly higher proportion of revenue being spent on marketing and sales activities. Additional narrative details describe increased advertising spend, higher advertising rates, and impacts from acquisitions and labor cost adjustments.
Technology and development

The table shows technology and development expenses across three fiscal years. Expenses increased from $48,698,000 in June 2020 to $54,428,000 in June 2021 (an 11.8% increase), and further to $56,561,000 in July 2022 (a 3.9% increase), indicating a slowdown in the rate of increase. The narrative highlights factors such as higher maintenance and support costs alongside savings from reduced labor costs.

elements.title: Financial Performance Metrics: G&A Expense and Depreciation & Amortization Trends

data.value: Expenses decreased from $117,136k in 2021 to $102,337k in 2022 (12.6% decrease) after a 20.3% increase from 2020, reflecting lower labor costs, reduced performance-related bonuses, and lower professional fees.
49078 k; +15.5% increase
42510 k; +30.7% increase

Depreciation and amortization expense increased steadily with a total rise of approximately 51% from 2020 to 2022, driven by investments in automation, IT enhancements, acquisitions, and related amortization adjustments.

elements.title: Interest Expense Comparison Across Fiscal Years

data.value: Interest expense, net
N/A

Interest expense, net increased significantly from $2,438,000 in June 2020 to $5,860,000 in June 2021 (a 140.4% increase) and then decreased by 3.3% in fiscal 2022, influenced by amendments to the Company’s credit facility and incremental debt used for the acquisition of PersonalizationMall.

elements.title: Other Income/Expense Comparison Across Fiscal Years

data.value: Other (income) expense, net

Other income/expense figures show a dramatic shift from a $5,888 thousand income in June 2021 to a $5,332 thousand expense in July 2022, with extreme volatility noted as a 7,109.5% change compared to June 2020. The fiscal 2022 expense includes losses from NQDC deferred compensation investments and impairments on certain investments.

Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates – Discussion of the basis for financial statements and the role of management judgments in estimating assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses.
1-800-FLOWERS.COM, Inc.
U.S. generally accepted accounting principles
Estimates and assumptions affecting asset values, liabilities, revenue, expenses and contingent disclosures; evaluated on an ongoing basis based on historical experience and other factors.
Represents excess of purchase price over fair value of net assets acquired; not amortized but subject to annual impairment testing with qualitative (Step 0) and quantitative (Step 1) methods.
Includes definite-lived intangibles (amortized over 3 to 16 years) and indefinite-lived intangibles (not amortized).
Utilizes both income and market approaches, including discounted cash flow and guideline public company method, with reconciliation to market capitalization.
Recognizes that actual results could differ based on economic conditions, market fluctuations, and changes in underlying assumptions, potentially resulting in impairment losses.

elements.title: Table of Contents - Impairment Testing and Income Taxes

data.value: Definite-lived intangible assets are reviewed for impairment when changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amounts may not be recoverable. A recoverability test is performed by comparing projected undiscounted cash flows with carrying value, and if cash flows are less, an impairment charge is recorded based on fair value determined by discounting future cash flows.
Tested for impairment at least annually or when triggering events occur. A qualitative 'Step 0' test may be used to assess if a quantitative test is necessary.

The asset and liability method is used to account for income taxes, with deferred tax assets and liabilities established for temporary differences. Recognition of deferred tax assets depends on future taxable income and other factors, with uncertain tax positions measured by the largest benefit with a greater than 50% likelihood of realization.

The assessment requires significant judgments and assumptions regarding cash flows, discount rates, and economic factors which could lead to revisions and, if necessary, recognition of impairment losses.

data.key: Deferred Income Tax - Net Deferred Tax Assets (FY2022)
Deferred Income Tax - Gross Deferred Tax Assets (FY2022)
Deferred Income Tax - Net Deferred Tax Liabilities (FY2022)

data.value: The tables provide a reconciliation of the statutory tax rate with the effective tax rate over three fiscal years and detail the components of deferred income tax assets and liabilities. Notable trends include a significant reduction in the effective tax rate from 24.29% in 2020 to 4.8% in 2022, adjustments in valuation allowances (including a reduction of approximately $6.2M due to expired capital loss carryforwards), and various changes in deferred tax components.

The segment analysis table indicates that net revenues from 2020 to 2022 grew from approximately $1.49B in 2020 to $2.21B in 2022. The key business segments are Consumer Floral & Gifts, BloomNet, and Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets. Consumer Floral & Gifts and Gourmet Foods & Gift Baskets are the largest contributors, while Corporate revenues are minimal and intercompany eliminations show negative adjustments.

The operating income breakdown by segment over the same periods shows a significant decline in 2022, with operating income dropping to $42.1M from $149.1M in 2021. The data further highlights that segment contribution margins, after accounting for Corporate expenses, depreciation and amortization, have been adversely impacted, indicating tighter margins in 2022.

This table presents a detailed revenue breakdown for a multi-segment business over three fiscal years (2020-2022). E-commerce is the dominant revenue source, accounting for approximately 88% of total revenues in 2022 ($1.93B out of $2.21B total). Total net revenues show consistent growth, increasing from $1.49B in 2020 to $2.21B in 2022, representing roughly 48% growth over this period. Within the 'Other Revenues' category, Wholesale and BloomNet services are the largest contributors, while Corporate revenue and Eliminations represent relatively minor components.

elements.title: Leases Note and Operating Lease Metrics Disclosure

data.value: The Company leases plants, warehouses, offices, store facilities, and equipment under long-term and short-term leases (per ASC 842). Lease agreements include renewal options and rent escalation clauses; variable costs like utilities, insurance, and taxes are expensed as incurred. At inception, the Company assesses if a contract contains a lease by evaluating rights over the asset's use and benefits.

At lease commencement, operating leases are recognized as a lease liability (measured as the present value of fixed minimum rental payments) and a corresponding right-of-use asset on the Balance Sheet. Short-term leases under 12 months benefit from an election to not apply the full recognition requirements.
Total lease costs are reported as 39,477, comprising operating lease costs (14,308), variable lease costs (19,342), short-term lease costs (6,639) and offset by sublease income (-812).

Cash paid for operating lease liabilities increased from 14,802 (June 27, 2021) to 16,486 (July 3, 2022). Right-of-use assets obtained increased from 30,622 to 57,494 over the same periods, reflecting an 87.8% increase. The weighted-average remaining lease term decreased from 9.5 years to 8.7 years, while the discount rate saw a slight increase from 3.8% to 3.9%.
Significant judgments include determining lease payments, lease term, and the discount rate (using the estimated collateralized incremental borrowing rate based on respective lease yield curves).

elements.title: Intellectual Property and Human Capital Disclosures

data.value: The Company relies on trademark, copyright, trade secret protection and contracts to safeguard its proprietary rights, yet acknowledges that competitors may still obtain or use its information, potentially leading to infringement, misappropriation, and costly, time-consuming litigation.

The Company emphasizes attracting and retaining skilled talent, offers competitive compensation, benefits, and diversity initiatives, and highlights its efforts in employee training, safety protocols (including COVID-19 measures), and inclusive corporate culture.
Under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, our disclosures contain forward-looking statements.
Based on management’s plans and assumptions regarding future actions, marketing effectiveness, performance of products, and customer retention.
Economic conditions, consumer spending patterns, high unemployment, credit market volatility, and impacts from COVID-19.
Actual results could differ materially, and no obligation to update forward-looking statements.
Effective consumer spending may be affected by various factors, including unemployment, debt levels, and market uncertainty.

elements.title: Risk Factors Associated with COVID-19 Pandemic

data.value: Exposure to risks associated with the pandemic has led to challenging operating environments.
Various measures including travel bans, quarantines, and business shutdowns have been implemented.
Considerable uncertainty regarding future demand for products due to pandemic measures.
Potential disruptions in supply chain and increases in operating costs.
Significant workforce inability may negatively impact operations.
Remote work has increased demand on IT resources and cyberattack vulnerabilities.
Public concern about contracting COVID-19 affects consumer demand.
Economic uncertainty affects business partners' ability to purchase products.
COVID-19 has led to volatility in capital, credit markets, and economic conditions.
Implemented protocols to mitigate COVID-19 impacts, with uncertain success.
Deteriorating conditions may lead to lower consumer spending on products.
Our recent growth rates may not be sustainable or indicative of our future growth.
Our ability to maintain the increased sales we have experienced since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic is uncertain, which could result in volatility of our stock price.
The Company's operating results may fluctuate, causing financial results to be below expectations.
Sales of the Company's products are seasonal, concentrated in the fourth calendar quarter and the second calendar quarter.
The Company may be unable to reduce operating expenses quickly enough to offset any unexpected revenue shortfall.
The Company depends on its customer service department to respond effectively to customer inquiries.
If the Company fails to develop and maintain its brands, it may not increase or maintain its customer base or revenues.
Failure to maintain high product and service quality could diminish the value of the 1-800-FLOWERS.COM brands, leading to customer loss and declining revenues.
Reliance on strategic relationships with third-party websites, search engines, and affiliates is critical; insufficient traffic from these sources may adversely affect online revenues.
Dependence on local florists and independent vendors for order fulfillment introduces risks, as any shortcomings in their service could result in customer dissatisfaction, delays, and revenue loss.

The company faces intense competition across multiple categories (floral, plants, gift baskets, gourmet food, etc.), which could lead to reduced market share and lost revenues if competitors perform better.
Continual improvements to the website, including mobile platforms, are essential; failure to enhance accessibility and user experience may hinder customer retention and reduce sales.

elements.title: Information Technology and Systems – Cybersecurity and Operational Risks

data.value: Failure to protect our website, networks and computer systems against disruption and cyber security threats could damage customer relationships, harm reputation, expose the company to litigation, and adversely affect the business.
Includes risks from computer viruses, malicious attacks, targeted or random security breaches, and unauthorized access to confidential information.
Reliance on computer systems for corporate email, design, manufacturing, digital marketing, e-commerce, credit card processing, and other operations.
Potential impact from credit card, debit card, and gift card fraud could lead to decreased revenues and damaged reputation.
System interruptions, long response times, degradation of service, or interruptions during peak periods could incur substantial repair costs and affect overall performance.

The Company relies on third-party telecommunications providers for maintaining customer service centers and connectivity with data centers; failure in these services could lead to system failures and revenue decline.

Although redundant systems are maintained, failures or inadequate maintenance by these providers may cause service interruptions, impacting revenue generation and incurring significant unanticipated costs.

A material weakness in controls over logical access and segregation of duties in certain IT environments has been identified, potentially leading to material misstatements in financial statements and affecting disclosure controls.

Unauthorized use or infringement of the Company’s intellectual property by third parties could damage its brands, reputation, and lead to lost sales, with additional complications arising from foreign registration challenges.
Non-compliance by franchisees with operating standards or franchise agreements may result in significant costs including litigation expenses and potential default under primary leases.
Loss of control over important brand identifiers such as phone numbers (e.g., 1-800-FLOWERS) or domain names due to third-party acquisition or FCC rules may confuse customers and harm the brand.

elements.title: Table of Contents - Risk Factors and Regulatory Environment

data.value: The document outlines that many governmental regulations, both existing and new, may impact the Internet and the Company's ability to conduct business globally. Regulations on issues such as intellectual property, user privacy, taxation, and product quality are highlighted as potential adverse factors.

It describes proposed regulations by the Federal Trade Commission regarding personal identifying information, requiring transparency in privacy and security policies, and imposing consent, access, correction, and deletion requirements, which could affect the Company's marketing and data collection efforts.

The text discusses the volatility of the Company’s Class A common stock, the possibility of significant price fluctuations, and the risk of securities class action litigation which could lead to diverted management attention and additional expenses.

The document provides information on where to access further reports such as the Annual Report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports through the Company’s website and the SEC website. It also notes a consent decree from a similar investigation and stresses the potential impact of regulatory actions.
There are no unresolved comments from the SEC staff regarding the current or periodic reports as of the stated period.

data.value: The Company is exposed to market risk from interest rate changes and market values of its investments.
A 50 basis point increase in current interest rates would increase the Company’s interest expense by approximately $1.0 million.

Material weakness related to logical access and segregation of duties in certain IT environments.
Management concluded that the financial statements are prepared in accordance with GAAP and fairly present the financial position and results.
1-800-FLOWERS.COM, Inc. is a leading provider of gifts designed to help customers express, connect and celebrate.

1-800-Flowers.com®, 1-800-Baskets.com®, Cheryl’s Cookies®, Harry & David®, PersonalizationMall.com®, Shari’s Berries®, FruitBouquets.com®, Moose Munch®, The Popcorn Factory®, Wolferman’s Bakery®, Vital Choice®, Stock Yards® and Simply Chocolate®.
Celebrations Passport® loyalty program provides members with free standard shipping and no service charge.
The Company operates BloomNet®, Napco℠, DesignPac Gifts, LLC, and Alice’s Table®.
The Company’s fiscal year is a 52- or 53-week period ending on the Sunday nearest to June 30.
Ended on July 3, 2022, and consisted of 53 weeks.
Each consisted of 52 weeks ending on June 27, 2021 and June 28, 2020, respectively.

elements.title: Management’s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting

data.value: Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
Internal control over financial reporting is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act.
Management concluded that the Company’s internal control over financial reporting was not effective as of July 3, 2022.
A material weakness is defined as a deficiency in internal control such that there's a reasonable possibility of material misstatement.
Identified deficiencies related to design of controls over logical access and segregation of duties.
Management has taken steps to remediate these deficiencies.
BDO USA, LLP audited the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting.

$2.3 million as of July 3, 2022 and June 27, 2021.

On April 1, 2020, litigation was initiated alleging a breach of the Equity Purchase Agreement. The matter was settled with a purchase of PersonalizationMall for $245.0 million, closing on August 3, 2020, following a settlement agreement and dismissal with prejudice.

A putative class action filed in March 2018 alleging FLSA violations resulted in a settlement agreement in April 2022 with a capped liability of up to $3.3 million, pending judicial approvals expected in Q3 fiscal 2023.

elements.title: CEO Letter - Operational and Supply Chain Update

data.value: Our balance sheet remains strong
Expectation of benefits from lower capital expenditures
Anticipated improvements contributing to overall financial strength
Proactive decision in fiscal 2022 to buy and build inventory ahead of the holiday season
Inventory strategy implemented to reduce exposure to global supply chain challenges, with reversal expected in the current fiscal year
Signed by Chris McCann, Chief Executive Officer, emphasizing commitment to growth and customer engagement

elements.title: Table of Contents Sources and Availability of Raw Materials

data.value: Ingredients for manufactured products including sugar, flour, cacao, eggs, fruit, flowers; packaging supplies; and transportation-related supplies such as fuel, natural gas and derivative products.
All raw materials, except certain crops from company-owned orchards, are purchased from third-party suppliers, including some single-source suppliers.
Prices and availability of raw materials are subject to fluctuation, and changes in these prices may or may not be passed on to customers.
Utilizes a global supply chain with both U.S. and international suppliers, who must adhere to local labor, safety, and applicable laws.
The timely acquisition and adequate volume of materials directly affects production capabilities, business growth, and merchandise appeal.

The company experiences seasonal fluctuations with significant revenue concentration in the second fiscal quarter due to holiday seasons. Additional fluctuations occur during other key periods like Mother’s Day and Valentine’s Day.
In anticipation of seasonal demand, the company increases inventories financed by cash flows and supplemented by revolving bank lines of credit, which are repaid before the end of the peak season.
Faces intense competition in various product categories from both traditional and online retailers, mass merchants, and specialty outlets.

elements.title: Supply Chain Disruptions and Increased Shipping Costs

data.value: Increased shipping costs from carriers such as Federal Express may force the company to pass on higher costs to customers.
Ocean container availability issues, port disruptions, and constrained carrier capacity could delay product deliveries.
Dependence on international vendors for flowers and components exposes the company to regulatory, economic, and political risks.
Trade policies, tariffs, and potential changes such as LIBOR discontinuation may also negatively affect the company's operations.
